It’s not even a question.  I guess you guys over there in Britain still don’t get it.

snippet.textDisplay: Population of N.Ireland: 1.8M  population of Scotland 5M (population of London alone = over 8M). This is a ridiculous idea imo. Totally uneconomical. Portpatrick also is just a sleepy little village that doesn't even have a duel carriageway!  And the A77 that runs out of Portpatrick runs through numerous other sleepy and even smaller little villages before you get anywhere near a decent main trunk road! Where's the infrastructure on the Scottish side?  I bet the residents of those quiet little villages would be thrilled.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a resident of the area in Scotland I can say that the roads to and from Portpatrick are ill equipped to handle the kind of traffic that would cause. There are already 2 ferry links in Cairnryan and the bridge, if it ever happened, would only cause a loss in business for them and possibly even cause one of them to stop entirely. In Stranraer, the former home of the Stena Line ferry, the port has just been abandoned by the company causing it look like a horrible wasteland and that’s also where the train comes in so it’s the first thing you see.

TL;DR
The roads can’t handle it and we’ve already been screwed over by the ferry companies so let’s not piss them off.
snippet.textOriginal:

There are already 2 ferry links in Cairnryan and the bridge, if it ever happened, would only cause a loss in business for them and possibly even cause one of them to stop entirely. In Stranraer, the former home of the Stena Line ferry, the port has just been abandoned by the company causing it look like a horrible wasteland and that’s also where the train comes in so it’s the first thing you see.

TL;DR
The roads can’t handle it and we’ve already been screwed over by the ferry companies so let’s not piss them off.

snippet.textDisplay: TLDR looking for a hot new controversy post brexit

snippet.textDisplay: Oh boy, this is going to make things so much more complicated. Imagine it. Scotland leaves the UK and re-joins the EU. Now, in order to transport goods from England to Ireland, you have to move them from England into the EU through Scotland, only to move them back out of the EU to get to Northern Ireland, only to again re-enter the EU in real Ireland.
snippet.textOriginal: Oh boy, this is going to make things so much more complicated. Imagine it. Scotland leaves the UK and re-joins the EU. Now, in order to transport goods from England to Ireland, you have to move them from England into the EU through Scotland, only to move them back out of the EU to get to Northern Ireland, only to again re-enter the EU in real Ireland.

snippet.textDisplay: So let's say such a bridge is constructed between N. Ireland and Scotland... and then Scotland leave the Union. Do we crumble that bridge and try for an even longer bridge between N. Ireland and England just to show how united the union still is in light of Scotland leaving?
snippet.textOriginal: So let's say such a bridge is constructed between N. Ireland and Scotland... and then Scotland leave the Union. Do we crumble that bridge and try for an even longer bridge between N. Ireland and England just to show how united the union still is in light of Scotland leaving?

snippet.textDisplay:
That is actually an interesting project that could possibly make Northern Ireland more connected to the rest of the UK at a time where Irish unionists want to unite Ireland.

It could also possibly improve Northern Ireland and Scotland by driving more traffic there.

In addition to all that, I'd say having a bridge this magnificent would be good for the UK.

If costs and feasibility are managed, I don't see why the huge opposition. Skepticism is good, but I think the project shouldn't be completely disregarded because it's difficult.
snippet.textOriginal:
That is actually an interesting project that could possibly make Northern Ireland more connected to the rest of the UK at a time where Irish unionists want to unite Ireland.

It could also possibly improve Northern Ireland and Scotland by driving more traffic there.

In addition to all that, I'd say having a bridge this magnificent would be good for the UK.

If costs and feasibility are managed, I don't see why the huge opposition. Skepticism is good, but I think the project shouldn't be completely disregarded because it's difficult.

snippet.textDisplay:
Given that Scotland would prefer to be a part of the EU, and that Ireland is a nation divided by what had been an occupying power, the bridge could become a problem.
What if Scotland did secede so that the goods must pass one customs border into Scotland, then another one into Northern Ireland and perhaps a third one if the goods were to reach Southern Ireland. The political ramifications are greater than the engineering ones and they are bad enough.
snippet.textOriginal:
Given that Scotland would prefer to be a part of the EU, and that Ireland is a nation divided by what had been an occupying power, the bridge could become a problem.
What if Scotland did secede so that the goods must pass one customs border into Scotland, then another one into Northern Ireland and perhaps a third one if the goods were to reach Southern Ireland.  The political ramifications are greater than the engineering ones and they are bad enough.

snippet.textDisplay:
First things First: Technically, there is not a snowball's chance in hell of a bridge being built.
Given the length, depth of water, currents, winds, it is absolutely impossible to build the bridge. There is no question about this. There is no bridge anywhere in the world which comes close to being comparable.
Therefore, the proposal can only be 100% political or for the benefit of the companies which could make millions from consultancy.
snippet.textOriginal:

Therefore, the proposal can only be 100% political or for the benefit of the companies which could make millions from consultancy.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am an American, and not at all familiar with the UK legal system.

But to me, in a time where Northern Ireland is said by many to moving away from Britian once more, and Scotland seems to be considering breaking away to remain in the EU (last I heard, anyway. It's been hard to keep up with everything) - it seems more like a move to assert British control of the area. I don't know how effective it would be, but I could see a play along the lines of:

"The british taxes payers supplied the funds for that Bridge. If Scotland breaks from the Union, you have to pay back the cost of its construction" or some similar line of protest, as a way to "price out" exiting the union as an option.
snippet.textOriginal:
I am an American, and not at all familiar with the UK legal system.

But to me, in a time where Northern Ireland is said by many to moving away from Britian once more, and Scotland seems to be considering breaking away to remain in the EU (last I heard, anyway. It's been hard to keep up with everything) - it seems more like a move to assert British control of the area. I don't know how effective it would be, but I could see a play along the lines of:

"The british taxes payers supplied the funds for that Bridge. If Scotland breaks from the Union, you have to pay back the cost of its construction" or some similar line of protest, as a way to "price out" exiting the union as an option.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's yet another diversionary tactic by Boris. He's attempting to distance himself from the Garden Bridge fiasco by touting this so that if you Google "Boris Bridge" it comes up with this instead. He did the same with "Boris Bus" when he claimed to enjoy making busses in an interview before the election.
The bridge itself is surely unfeasible. It would barely be open due to the weather, meaning companies could not rely on it for shipping, therefore making other arrangements. The sheer size of the towers would have to be enormous too- you're looking at trying to install dozens of 500m tall towers in one of the roughest seas around. All this from the government that couldn't even build a single one of the thousands of houses they promised in the previous election.
snippet.textOriginal:
It's yet another diversionary tactic by Boris. He's attempting to distance himself from the Garden Bridge fiasco by touting this so that if you Google "Boris Bridge" it comes up with this instead. He did the same with "Boris Bus" when he claimed to enjoy making busses in an interview before the election. 
The bridge itself is surely unfeasible. It would barely be open due to the weather, meaning companies could not rely on it for shipping, therefore making other arrangements. The sheer size of the towers would have to be enormous too- you're looking at trying to install dozens of 500m tall towers in one of the roughest seas around. All this from the government that couldn't even build a single one of the thousands of houses they promised in the previous election.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why Scotland? Is he trying to buy votes with a huge project in Scotland?

We have experience of a long tunnel with the channel tunnel. Why a bridge?

The capital expenditure alone is vast. But if Scotland leaves the UK how do we get that money back? Or cost the loss of use for that vital infrastructure?

With the extreme weather how often do they think a bridge will be open or safe to use?

When the British nuclear fleet is based up there this is somewhat short sighted.

£15-£20billion, that's ridiculous try 10x that and that's initially. It will be several times that by the end. Not including all the added expense of additional roads and storage yards on each end.
snippet.textOriginal:
Why Scotland? Is he trying to buy votes with a huge project in Scotland?

We have experience of a long tunnel with the channel tunnel. Why a bridge?

The capital expenditure alone is vast. But if Scotland leaves the UK how do we get that money back? Or cost the loss of use for that vital infrastructure?

With the extreme weather how often do they think a bridge will be open or safe to use?

When the British nuclear fleet is based up there this is somewhat short sighted.

£15-£20billion, that's ridiculous try 10x that and that's initially. It will be several times that by the end. Not including all the added expense of additional roads and storage yards on each end.

snippet.textDisplay:
Doing it would require sorting out the infrastructure missing in both Scotland & Northern Ireland:
From what I've seen, none of the Motorways in Northern Ireland actually connect cites, ports or even airports together. Come on, Belfast & Derry don't have a motorway? Every major city in the Republic is connected to the network. Larne doesn't have a motorway & the road to Dublin in the North isn't one either.
As for Scotland: Motorways would need to be built from Gretna Green & Glasgow along with extending the rail line to Portpatrick.

However, I see it as a Unionist ploy: By starting such an expensive project in a separatist region, if Scotland sought independence they'd have to take partial responsibility for the bridge. If Irish reunification happened, it would be a huge disaster for the Irish state as we can't afford it. So to hell with infrastructure, building it is a real attempt to force the UK to stick together.
snippet.textOriginal:
Doing it would require sorting out the infrastructure missing in both Scotland & Northern Ireland:
From what I've seen, none of the Motorways in Northern Ireland actually connect cites, ports or even airports together. Come on, Belfast & Derry don't have a motorway? Every major city in the Republic is connected to the network. Larne doesn't have a motorway & the road to Dublin in the North isn't one either.
As for Scotland: Motorways would need to be built from Gretna Green & Glasgow along with extending the rail line to Portpatrick.

However, I see it as a Unionist ploy: By starting such an expensive project in a separatist region, if Scotland sought independence they'd have to take partial responsibility for the bridge. If Irish reunification happened, it would be a huge disaster for the Irish state as we can't afford it. So to hell with infrastructure, building it is a real attempt to force the UK to stick together.

snippet.textDisplay: I can see why he wants it, to keep the Union together. Too expensive. Ireland will be better off as one nation. Scotland will also be better off without England, as England is at the moment. The bridge would link a United Ireland with a separate Scotland & may benefit those 2 countries within the EU, but not directly joined to the rest of the EU. Lastly, with climate breakdown & rising sea levels the bridge, as a project, is probably rather fool-hardy.

Lastly, with climate breakdown & rising sea levels the bridge, as a project, is probably rather fool-hardy.
